summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2020 between FBI personnel and a forensic examiner, coordinating the transfer and review of hard drives (HDs) and devices seized in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The emails discuss making evidence available to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) and the need to expedite the process due to the case's high profile.

persons.name: Stephen
persons.context: Addressed in emails as the point of contact for forensic examination of Epstein-related hard drives and devices. He indicates the evidence has been available and offers to ship items to the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Coordination for SDNY Evidence Access
events.description: An email instructs ensuring the Southern District of New York (SDNY) is aware of and knows how to access forensic evidence (hard drives and devices) from the Epstein case.

events.title: Forensic Evidence Status Update
events.description: A forensic examiner (Stephen) reports that all devices and media have been available in the CAIR system for over a year, exports are nearly complete, and items can be shipped to the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Arrangement for Hard Drive Transfer
events.description: FBI personnel discuss obtaining external hard drives to facilitate the transfer of Epstein case evidence and coordinating the review process with SDNY.

keyFacts: Forensic evidence from the Epstein case, including multiple hard drives and devices, was being managed by the FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) in New York over a year after the initial seizures.
The Southern District of New York (SDNY) was actively involved and required access to this digital evidence for their review, indicating an ongoing investigation.
The emails highlight internal FBI coordination to expedite the evidence transfer process due to the high-profile nature ('Given the attention this case is getting') of the Epstein case.
Several names and email addresses are redacted in the correspondence, indicating standard operational security within law enforcement communications.
